block.p: Informal Talks Reported On Exit Terms for Milosevic The Clinton administration is exploring with some of its NATO allies and Russia the possibility that President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia could be allowed to leave office with guarantees for his safety and his savings, American and NATO officials say.

Informal Talks Reported On Exit Terms for Milosevic The Clinton administration is exploring with some of its NATO allies and Russia the possibility that President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia could be allowed to leave office with guarantees for his safety and his savings, American and NATO officials say.

More U.S. Travel to Cuba The Clinton administration is opening Cuba to American travelers at a rate not seen in more than 40 years by relaxing rules and applying only a spotty enforcement of travel restrictions. The new flow has given rise to a flurry of new contacts, and there is a renewed push to relax the commercial boycott.

Old Tactics in Mexico Campaign Opposition leaders in Mexico contend that the governing party's long-entrenched practices of vote-buying, coercion and doling out pork have not changed, although the current presidential campaign is still the fairest in the country's history.

Harsh Words From North Korea North Korea, four days after historic reconciliation talks, accused the United States, which has 37,000 troops stationed in South Korea, of increasing the danger of war in the Korean peninsula. The accusation came just two days after the United States said it had no plans to withdraw from South Korea.
Action Backs Annan on Lebanon The Security Council gave a qualified endorsement of Secretary General Kofi Annan's certification on Friday that Israel has withdrawn from Lebanon.

Horn of Africa Truce The war between Ethiopia and Eritrea came to an official halt, closing two years of fighting in one of the fiercest wars in Africa, as the nations signed a preliminary cease-fire.

South Africa Quiet on Zimbabwe South Africa, the beacon of democracy and the uncontested power of sub-Saharan Africa, remains silent as Zimbabwe lurches toward parliamentary elections next weekend and growing numbers of opposition party supporters have been beaten, killed and intimidated.

Syria Party Backs Assad Son The governing Baath Party of Syria unanimously elected Bashar al-Assad, the son and heir apparent to the late President Hafez al-Assad, as its secretary general, on the second day of a crucial party congress.
Europe Warns Britain on Soccer European soccer's governing body warned that England might face expulsion from Euro 2000, the continent's soccer championships, if its fans persist in violence.

Jordan King Fires Conservative King Abdullah of Jordan dismissed the conservative prime minister, Abdul Rauf al-Rawabdeh, and replaced him with a change-oriented politician with strong business credentials, officials said.

Federal Tax Credits In Gore Retirement Plan Vice President Al Gore plans to propose in a speech tomorrow a $200 billion program to help low- and middle-income taxpayers build retirement accounts separate from what they will receive from Social Security, his aides said. The program would work like 401(k) savings plans, but instead of employer contributions, the federal government would make contributions in the form of tax credits, providing in some cases up to a 3-to-1 match.

Risky Strategy for Scientist The lawyers for Wen Ho Lee, the scientist accused of mishandling nuclear weapons secrets, plan a courtroom assault in coming weeks that could all but decide the case before the trial if they win some crucial rulings. But should they lose, the strategy could also create serious risks for Dr. Lee's defense.

Call for Resignation The strange case of lost and found nuclear secrets at Los Alamos National Laboratory took on a political edge as some Republican leaders in Congress called on Energy Secretary Bill Richardson, above, to resign after yet another security lapse at the New Mexico laboratory.

Model for Health Coverage The array of health benefits that Vermont provides its residents is unmatched by any other state. And while many of the programs would not work in other states, some aspects could serve as models.
Waco Suit Going to Trial The trial in the Branch Davidian wrongful-death case is scheduled to open today in Federal District Court in Waco, Tex., six years after the lawsuit was filed.

Running Mate Secret With little more than a month to go before Gov. George W. Bush settles on the person with whom he wants to share the Republican presidential ticket, the list of possibilities seems to be getting shorter. And it is getting no clearer. Mr. Bush is holding his cards so close to the vest that even his most trusted advisers insist they have not been able to sneak a peek.
Egan Becomes Archbishop In Ceremony at Cathedral Edward M. Egan was invested as the ninth archbishop of New York, the nation's most visible Roman Catholic leader.
Cabby Is Punched, and Dies A yellow-cab driver died after being punched in the face by a passenger on Central Park South, the police said. The authorities did not classify the death as a homicide.
Another Arrest in Assaults The police arrested another man who they said participated in sexual attacks against women in Central Park after the National Puerto Rican Day Parade.
Near Miss at La Guardia A US Air Airbus and a smaller turboprop plane came within 100 feet of colliding last week, but the air-traffic controller responsible never reported the incident to the F.A.A.

Mrs. Clinton Assails Lazio Hillary Rodham Clinton intensified her criticism of Rick A. Lazio over the weekend, chastising her senate opponent for missing a vote on a plan to establish a oil reserve in the New York harbor area.
Noboru Takeshita A former prime minister who was forced to resign from office by a stocks-for-favors scandal and one of the legendary kingmakers of post-war politics in Japan, he was 76.
Woods Breaks Golf Records Tiger Woods won the 100th United States Open by 15 strokes, the largest margin of victory ever in a major championship.

White Sox Sweep Yankees The Chicago White Sox completed a four-game sweep of the Yankees with a 17-4 rout that began with a nine-run first inning. The Yankees had not allowed nine in a first inning since 1979 and the White Sox had not scored nine in a first in 38 years.

Vivendi and Seagram Deal Near Vivendi and the Seagram Company are preparing to vote today on Vivendi's purchase of Seagram for roughly $33 billion in stock. The companies' boards met over the weekend to discuss the deal, and an agreement could be announced by the end of the day.

Introducing AOLTV America Online today plans to introduce AOLTV, the centerpiece of the company's AOL Anywhere strategy to move beyond the personal computer. AOLTV is a black box enabling people to surf the Internet on their television screens. But it will also allow existing America Online members to keep access to their e-mail, chat rooms and buddy list while watching television.
America Online said that it would take steps to fix flaws in its network that allowed hackers to access personal information about some members last week.

CBS Lures Young Viewers ''Survivor,'' the hit series about survival and relationship tests on a tropical island near Borneo, has generated for CBS the kind of ratings with young viewers that normally are associated with shows on the Fox network or ABC.
Editorials: Tortured ideas on missile defense; death penalty troubles in Texas; Tina Rosenberg on a Colombian terror attack.
